title: Strategize To Make Profit In 'Dumsor'Business Owners Told
text:
Business & Finance | 7 August 2015 16:05 CET Strategize To Make Profit In 'Dumsor'â€¦Business Owners Told By Daily Guide 
Dignitaries inspecting some of the products on display at the trade fair 
Business owners in the country have been admonished to adopt new strategies to reach out to their clients in order to sustain their businesses in the wake of the energy crisis also known as 'Dumsor.' 
Jim Aglah, General Manager of Multi Media Group Ltd, Kumasi, who gave the advice, said the energy crisis was negatively impacting businesses and Ghanaians in general. 
In these difficult times, he stated, businesses owners and leaders need to be proactive and innovative so as to remain in business owing to the debilitating effects of the power crisis. 
'In this distressing period of energy crisis which has caused some businesses to collapse, it is important to explore non-traditional ways to reaching out to our equally frustrated customers to boost sales and keep our businesses afloat.' 
Mr. Aglah disclosed this while speaking at the official opening of the 2015 edition of the Luv FM Trade and Technological Discount Fair, which saw business entities converge on the Golden Tulip in Kumasi for four days to display their products. 
The Luv FM Trade Fair was designed to create a one-stop shop for manufacturers, distributors, retailers, as well as service providers to showcase their products and services, he indicated. 
The General Manager of Multi Media Group Ltd in Kumasi said the event, apart from boosting sales, would also give consumers the opportunity to patronize quality products at one location. 
Kojo Bonsu, the Chief Executive of the Kumasi Metropolitan Assembly (KMA), in a speech read on his behalf, commended Luv FM for their vision in holding the trade fair to help boost sales and promote businesses, urging them to sustain their good works. 
Robert Nketia, Ashanti Regional Chairman of the Association of Ghana Industries (AGI), admitted that industries in the country were facing numerous challenges under the prevailing circumstances in the country. 
The trade fair, he noted, would help participating firms to get exposure, create links and boost their profits. 
FROM I.F. Joe Awuah Jnr., Kumasi
